channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: US, China Officials Agree on Plan That Awaits Xi, Trump Sign-Off
item.description: The US and China capped two days of high-stakes trade talks with a plan to revive the flow of sensitive goods — a framework now awaiting the blessing of Donald Trump and Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

item.title: Romanian Pro-EU Election Result Lifts Economy, Top Bank CEO Says
item.description: Romania’s economy is poised for a boost from the election of a pro-European president, outweighing risks from fiscal imbalances and US President Donald Trump’s tariff war, according to the head of the country’s biggest bank.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

item.title: US Tariff Limbo Gives Canadian Warehouses a New Lease on Life
item.description: With US bonded facilities increasingly full, importers find that stockpiling goods north of the border works just as well.
item.dc:creator: Ari Altstedter

media:content.media:description: Workers at Windsor Fulfillment Corp. unload a truck earlier this month.

item.title: ECB’s Lane Says June Cut Helps Keep Price Undershoot Temporary
item.description: The European Central Bank’s latest reduction in borrowing costs will guard against inflation getting stuck below 2%, according to Chief Economist Philip Lane.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

item.title: Traders Boost Bets on Just One 2025 Fed Cut Ahead of CPI
item.description: Traders are increasingly betting that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates only once this year amid signs of resilient growth and sticky inflation.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

item.title: Mexico’s Pledge to Give Deportees Jobs Hits Snag Over US Flights
item.description: Mexico’s government has pledged to provide jobs for citizens deported from the US, but recent data shows that barely 4% of the tens of thousands expelled since late January have been matched with employment.
item.dc:creator: Amy Stillman, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Migrants at the Mexican refugee commission, following the suspension of CBP One appointments, in Tapachula, Mexico, on Jan. 27.

item.title: Bank of England Urges Lenders to Step Up Repo Facilities Use
item.description: The Bank of England has urged lenders to step up use of its routine liquidity facilities to avoid possible stresses in markets as the central bank runs down its balance sheet.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: The Bank of England in the City of London. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

item.title: Euro’s Steady Demand Shows Challenge of Taking On the Dollar
item.description: International use of the euro remained flat for another year in 2024, laying bare the depth of the task in challenging the US dollar on the global stage.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: North Korea Appears to Have Added to Its Nuclear Complex
item.description: North Korea appears to have constructed a new building within its main nuclear complex, satellite imagery showed, in what could be an additional enrichment facility to ramp up the country’s ability to produce nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kim Jae-Hwan/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images) Photographer: SOPA Images/SOPA Images

item.title: Hungary Inflation Quickens, Pushing Forint to Two-Month High
item.description: Hungarian inflation accelerated in May for the first time in three months, underscoring the central bank’s challenge in returning price growth toward its target. The forint gained.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik, Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: The Lehel Market Hall food market in Budapest. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Wage Tracker Signals Pay Growth Will Plunge This Year
item.description: Wage growth in the euro zone will slow sharply in 2025, according to the European Central Bank’s main gauge of future pay increases – bolstering arguments that inflation is under control.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

item.title: ECB’s Kazaks Says Some Fine-Tuning Rate Cuts ‘Quite Likely’
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Martins Kazaks said further interest-rate cuts may be needed, according to Econostream Media.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Martins Kazaks Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Cambodia’s Exports to the US Soar as Trump Tariff Hikes Linger
item.description: Cambodia’s exports to the US rose 27% through the first five months compared to the same period last year amid signs of front-loading following President Donald Trump’s pledge to raise tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Containers at the Sihanoukville Autonomous Port in Cambodia. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Exports Flood Southeast Asia on US Tariffs, Citi Says
item.description: Vietnam, Thailand and Indonesia are among Asian countries seeing the sharpest surge in Chinese imports as higher US tariffs upend regional trade, according to Citigroup Inc.
item.dc:creator: Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: A Chinese export truck drives past a durian wholesale market on May 9, 2025 in Chanthaburi, Thailand.

item.title: South Africa Statistics Chief Defends Jobless-Data Calculations
item.description: The head of South Africa’s statistics agency defended the methodology of his organization’s unemployment data after the chief of the nation’s top bank by customers said misclassification of traders means the jobless rate was much lower.
item.dc:creator: Ana Monteiro

media:content.media:description: Commuters in Pretoria, South Africa.

item.title: EU Sees US Trade Talks Extending Beyond Trump’s July Deadline
item.description: The European Union believes trade negotiations with the US could extend beyond President Donald Trump’s July 9 deadline, even as the speed of the talks has increased over the past week.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: The Port of Barcelona. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Swedish Support for Joining Euro Fades as Krona Strengthens
item.description: Swedes’ enthusiasm to adopt the euro fell for the first time in four and a half years after a recent run of strength for the krona, a survey showed.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: Stores in Gothenburg, Sweden. Photographer: Fredrik Lerneryd/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Household Loans Climb, Adding to BOK, Regulator Concern
item.description: South Korea’s bank lending to households climbed the most in nine months, an increase that adds to concerns over growing debt at the central bank and the financial regulator as policymakers assess how much support to give the sputtering economy.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: India, US to Expedite Trade Talks Ahead of Trump’s Tariff Deadline
item.description: India and the US will expedite trade talks to conclude an agreement that includes “early wins” for both sides, an official said, as the two nations race to clinch a deal before Washington’s tit-for-tat tariffs kick in next month.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port in Navi Mumbai, India.

item.title: EU Ready for Second Attempt at Australia Trade Deal, Envoy Says
item.description: The European Union is ready and willing to make a second attempt at securing a free trade deal with Australia, EU Ambassador Gabriele Visentin said, while adding that the main obstacles to an accord that were identified in 2023 are largely unchanged.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

item.title: Land Rovers, Houses and Whisky: Gold Rally Brings Riches to Rural Zimbabwe
item.description: Surge in gold prices is driving a boom in Africa’s small-scale production
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: Brighton Moyo with a newly acquired BMW bought from gold proceeds at a car wash in Filabusi, a town in southern Zimbabwe.

item.title: Being a Bully on Trade Won’t Work Longer Term, Lagarde Warns
item.description: There’s no longer-term advantage to being a bully on global commerce, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde on June 5.

item.title: The Euro Struggles to Win Over Czechs Going Slow on Adoption
item.description: The Czech central bank governor touted the benefits of his country’s currency, saying that the koruna puts it in a better position to moderate price-growth than the euro would.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Krystof Chamonikolas, Kriti Gupta

media:content.media:description: Ales Michl in Prague, on June 10. Photographer: Milan Jaros/Bloomberg

item.title: New Zealand Immigration Decline May Impede Economic Recovery
item.description: New Zealand immigration fell to a two-and-a-half year low in April, adding to risks of a slower-than-expected economic recovery that could prompt more interest-rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: RBNZ Says Adrian Orr Resigned as Governor Over Funding Cut
item.description: New Zealand’s central bank said former governor Adrian Orr resigned over government cuts to the bank’s funding.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett, Tracy Withers

media:content.media:description: Adrian Orr Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

item.title: US Inflation Seen Picking Up With Some Tariff Pass-Through
item.description: Forecasters say underlying US inflation likely picked up in May, reflecting a modest impact from tariff pass-through for goods that are mostly imported, while some services like airfares saw smaller price gains or outright declines.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: Most BOJ Watchers Expect Slower Pace in Reducing Bond Purchases
item.description: A majority of Bank of Japan watchers expect officials to slow their pace of reductions in government bond buying and keep interest rates unchanged at next week’s policy meeting, according to a Bloomberg survey.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Cynthia Li

media:content.media:description: A Japanese flag flies outside the Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures.

item.title: Bessent Returns to Washington as US-China Talks Stretch On
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent departed trade talks with China late Tuesday in London, as delegations continued to negotiate over key tech and industrial exports and deescalating their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick on June 10.

item.title: Ghana Seeks to Shield Budget Goal as Nurses Strike Over Pay Deal
item.description: Ghana has asked its nurses to call off a strike and accept the implementation of a wage deal next year as it seeks to protect the 2025 budget from unplanned slippages.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

media:content.media:description: John Mahama

item.title: Canada’s Economy in ‘Suspended Animation’ During Trade War, CIBC Chief Says
item.description: Canada’s economy is stuck in a state of “suspended animation,” with major new investments largely on hold, but may start to recover in the coming months, according to the head of one of the country’s largest banks.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo

media:content.media:description: Victor Dodig, president and chief executive officer of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CIBC), at CIBC Square in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, June 17, 2022. In his eight years as chief executive officer of CIBC, Dodig has turned the lender into one of the country's fastest-growing banks. His next task is convincing investors the change will stick.
